body: @b-slim I'm trying to make less locking so the impact of one miss-behaving lookup extractor is minimal. Right now if ONE lookup stalls in its start() method, then the jetty thread is locked up as well as ANY management of lookups.

@fjy this issue is almost definitely not specifically related to the KafkaIndexTask or supervisor and probably not a regression introduced in 0.9.1 either, but seems to be some pre-existing weirdness where the RTR doesn't have a correct view of the cluster and doesn't realize there's available MM capacity; it's probably okay for us to push the fix to a later release
@drcrallen all QTL related properties were at their default values when we experienced this.

@drcrallen I think as-is, setting firstCacheTimeout to 0 will cause the manager to report failure in `scheduleAndWait`, leading to a bunch of error messages and also to `delete(id)` getting called. If it's meant to act async-y it should report success even if the task hasn't finished yet.

Thanks for looking @dclim. Good to hear its probably unrelated to KafkaIndexTask and I'll go multi-mm next week (just prototyping right now). I'll keep baking it and let y'all know if it re-occurs.

@drcrallen if you are locking a read lock while you are doing a put or update, what's the point to have a lock any way ? you are allowing multiple write in the same time. I think the way to do this is to make sure that lookup.start is executed asynchronously or by a different thread pool.

@b-slim The `startStopLock` is **NOT** for the manager lookup map state, it is for the manager start/stop state, in which case write locks during start and stop, and read locks elsewhere are correct.

@gianm and @drcrallen what do you think ?

One problem with LookupDimensionSpec that exists today is that the lookup can't be chained with any other extractions. Users can use the chained extraction fn to write filters like `SUBSTR(LOOKUP(foo, "mylookup"), 2, 4) = "bar"` but this is not possible with dimensionSpecs by themselves.

This would need to be addressed before LookupDimensionSpec is really able to replace extractionFns.

The other kind of nesting is also possible and also useful, i.e. both of,
- `SUBSTR(LOOKUP(foo, "mylookup"), 2, 4) = "bar"`
- `LOOKUP(SUBSTR(foo, 2, 4), "mylookup") = "bar"`

@gianm what you are saying make sense, but this mean if a lookup is embedded under extraction function, we can do something like mapping one to many or take advantage of applyAll. Not sure which way to go, do you have suggestions ?
@b-slim not sure what you mean by that, could you give an example of what you're thinking?
`getSupervisorStatus` doesn't need synchronization, but it does have a race because it does `supervisors.get(id)` twice. It should only do it once.

Currently lookups can not actually be one to many right?

But if they could, one possible way to deal with that is if you have a cascade, and layer N of the cascade generates potentially many values for every one value, then you handle that by running functions in layer N + 1 for each of those many values. So the cascade ends up returning potentially multiple values rather than just one value.

@drcrallen the overlord has lots of issues like the one you mentioned (a great many calls involve acquiring coarse locks, so there are a lot of opportunities to lock it up). Since the overlord doesn't do anything other than handle coordination (it doesn't accept queries) I don't think that's a show stopper problem. So I don't think we need to fix that before merging the PR. IMO the lack of thread safety on SupervisorManager is a bigger issue than coarse grained locking.
@gianm can you file a ticket about that and link it here? I'm ok with it being an acknowledged shortcoming since overlord locking up can be very quickly solved with a restart.

This performance change is pretty small. Was the benchmark performed on a laptop?

If so please conduct the test on a machine with a pinned frequency governor (see https://metamarkets.com/2015/effect-of-frequency-governor-on-java-benchmarking/ )
@drcrallen this PR is less about improving speed but more about reducing the size of serialized data produced by GenericIndexed and hence segment size.
@drcrallen I added exception handling to stop() and added a started flag to prevent the issue you described from occurring. Let me know if you have any other concerns. Thanks for the review!

Can you add in a state check to make sure an update can't occur when the manager is in the stopped state?

I've also did this once but found the difference was not big enough (~5%) to justify format inconsistency. I'm good on this change because we don't have any product cluster yet but it seemed hard to accepted for others.
@fjy done

I don't mean to spam your discussion with my input as I'm not too knowledgeable about the Druid internals, but if I may, I'd like to propose something while not knowing whether things already work that way or not nor do I know whether the proposal is sound or not.

To my understanding, segments do currently not contain any aggregates that have a higher granularity than that of the rolled up records. 
If a segment's block for a given metric had an aggregate value for the whole block, then one could reduce the computational cost for queries: 
If the bitmap of records to aggregate over has less than half of the bits set that make up one block, one would sum these values up as usual. If the bitmap had more than half of the bits set that make up one block, one would aggregate over the inverted bitmap and subtract the result from the pre-aggregated value that is stored for that block.
This would ensure that in the worst case, only half of a block's records would have to be aggregated.
Seeing how the query latency is mostly determined by how many records remain to be aggregated after filtering, it seems that the opportunity of cutting these in half is worth holding the pre-aggregated values.
Where to keep those aggregates is of course another topic. They could go into the segments or be kept in some cache....
this needs to be backported too to 0.9.1.
I'm gonna fix it on the server by optionally accepting comma separated list of things in a string in addition to a json array... UI sends comma separated list as a string , so that would work fine.
IMHO this should be handled at the UI and not in the service.
@drcrallen fixed merge conflicts
Does the UI already translate JSON arrays to csv when populating the text box? It'd need to do that for this fix to be effective.

@drcrallen i would agree with you about fix to UI but there does not seem to be anyone available who understands and can fix it there.
@gianm I tested the patch, UI can do deserialization fine without any problems. at deserialization time, it "converts" array of strings to a comma separated string.

@sascha-coenen it sounds like what you are proposing is some form of materialized views. The question then would be what time granularity to choose for those pre-aggregated records, since that may differ from the underlying segment granularity. Your example case would work for simple sum aggregations, but it would not necessarily extend to complex aggregations or even min / max aggregations, since those do not necessarily support subtracting rows. It sounds like this could help in a small number of use cases, but I'm not sure if it's worth the added complexity. Given that this is unrelated to the topic of this issue, I suggest opening a separate issue if you'd like to discuss further.

@drcrallen Yes, I ran this benchmark multiple times on a mac (and I was not browsing reddit at that time) and most of the times the performance change was small that lead me to think that it should not affect performance in production env. Regarding "pinned frequency governor machine" I have to read about it and then will try to run the benchmark on such machine.

@b-slim nothing's wrong with dimensionSpec in principle, I just wanted to point out that there are some things extractionFns can do that dimensionSpecs can't, which would need to be addressed before they can really be unified.

In particular, some that I can think of are,
- ability to chain with other extractionFns
- ability to expose `preservesOrdering` and `isOneToOne` for filters and query engines
- when used with filters, ability for filters like "selector" and "bound" to determine if they can use binary search of the dictionary or if they must do a full scan of the dictionary (I think `preservesOrdering` and `isOneToOne` are enough for this though)
